advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUASAR AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8 KB quasar system with the 4 color plotter/printer interface.<br><br> The small picture shows a complete system with memory expansion, modem and video interfaces.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #1 JAN. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Adopt a little gifted"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 3 PAGE U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First HX-20 U.S. advert (september 1982)<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The size, of course, is a dead giveaway. But don't let the size fool you. The HX-20 is not a toy. Or a glorified calculator.<br> It's a computer.<br> A real computer with 16K RAM<br>...<br> Surprised that a computer like the HX-20 should come from Epson?<br> You shouldn't be. Because we have been building computers in Japan since 1978. And we have been practicing ultra-high-quality precision manufacturing for a lot longer than that.<br><br> We didn't jump right into the American microcomputer market. We could afford to bide our time; to wait for the product that was going to stand America on its ears.<br> This is it.<br> The Epson HX-20</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL GUIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO 7, the family computer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #3 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The guy on the right is "Sidney", a well known french break dancer back in 1984 !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Basis 108. Microcomputin'g "Best Of Both Worlds"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil is an awesome manager"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE BUSINESS GRAPHICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Apple graphics package was launched in September 1982. It was available for both the Apple II and Apple III.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">As you know, one picture is worth a few thousand numbers.<br> As you may not know, Apple Business Graphics software can generate more types of pictures, in more colours, using more data than any other graphics package... On the monitor of your choice. And on virtually any printer or plotter on the market...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

computer.colors: 8 with two tones each (normal and bright)
computer.description:
The TK90X was the first Sinclair Spectrum clone produced by Microdigital. At the time, a special Brazilian regulation allowed local industry to produce and sell copies of foreign computers only to domestic market, however Microdigital computers were also sold in several south American countries.
Despite the case was quite the same as the original Spectrum, the TK90 wasn't fully compatible with it because of some additions to the software in ROM (User Defined Graphics editor, TRACE function, error messages in portuguese), and also some differences in I/O ports configuration and addresses. As a result a few games couldn't run on the TK90X, and some Sinclair peripherals could not be used.
The TK90X met a large success in Brazil thanks to a vast amount of pirated copies of Spectrum games available in the country.
Microdigital announced a Microdrive clone but it was never released. However, four other small companies (C.A.S., C.B.I., Syncron and Arcadia) released floppy disk drive interfaces. All interfaces were BetaDisk compatible. Except for the C.A.S. interface, all models had a built-in parallel printer interface. Other famous and very popular peripheral was the Multiface 1 interface. Most brazillian M1's were produced by C.A.S.
One year later, Microdigital launched an improved version, the TK-95 _______________________
computer.name: TK-90X
computer.peripherals: Sinclair (not all) and third sources peripherals
computer.ports: Expansion port, tape-recorder (1200 bauds), RF video out, Joystick

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TK90X</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Thomas Conté for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD PARTS</strong></font><br><blockquote>the keyboard is made of a sheet of rubber including all the keys, placed onto a printed circuit. When a key is pressed, a small conductive washer located below each key touches the circuit board and connects two tracks.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • DC power connector<br> • Expansion connector<br> • 9-pin joystick connector<br> • Tape recorder In/Out jacks<br> • RF video output to TV set</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CONNECTORS CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Thomas Conté for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> RF modulator and chinch jack<br> <b>(2)</b> Tape recorder In/Out jacks<br> <b>(3)</b> Joystick DB9 plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Extension connector<br> <b>(5)</b> 5V DC power regulator<br> <b>(6)</b> External 9V DC jack<br> <b>(7)</b> I/O chip<br> <b>(8)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Zilog Z80A processor<br> <b>(10)</b> Seems to be a copy a the Spectrum ULA custom chip (more info needed!)<br> <b>(11)</b> 48 KB RAM chips. The RAM chips are separated in two banks, 16KB in 8x4116 chips shared with video on a separated bus (framed) and 32KB in 4x4416 chips (right side of the frame) </blockquote>
